title: Embedded Prototyping
items: Developed and deployed bare-metal C code on an ATtiny85 microcontroller, using firmware to control the universal serial interface and communicate with a triple-axis accelerometer via I2C.
Assembled a toolchain using open source tools such as avr-libc, gcc, make, gdb, avrdude, and bloom for AVR development, In-System Programming, and hardware debugging.

title: Verilog Clock and Data Recovery (CDR)
items: Implemented a ``Multiple Rotating Clock Phase Architecture for Clock and Data Recovery'' described in an IEEE paper, using Verilog for entry, Icarus Verilog for compilation, and GTKWave as a wave viewer (\textcolor{cyan}{\href{https://github.com/L28E/MRCP-CDR}{link}}).
Verified individual modules with test benches, and implemented a pseudorandom bit sequence generator to verify the CDR's tracking ability.

title: Homelab
items: Self-hosted several services across an evolving collection of x86-64 and ARM systems running Linux.
Assembled and serviced many desktop and rack mount machines, including some component level repair.
Deployed services such as Jupyter Notebook, Jellyfin, Raspotify, Samba, VSFTPD, Navidrome, Heritrix.

title: Op-Amp Design
items: Created the schematic and layout of a two-stage CMOS op-amp in Cadence Virtuoso as a demonstration of basic op-amp design.
Fulfilled all of the ≥12 design specifications across various corners both pre-layout and post-layout, while adhering to area and layer constraints.

title: Programming and Demonstrating a Neural Network Training Method
items: Programmed the Nelder-Mead numerical method and a small multi-layer perceptron neural network in C to demonstrate artificial neural network structures and training methods (\textcolor{cyan}{\href{https://github.com/L28E/Downhill-Simplex-for-a-Simple-ANN}{link}}).
Applied training, testing, and validation procedures to train a model representing a non-linear problem.

title: Implementing a Z80-like Processor with Modern EDA Tools
items: Authored a report documenting the present state as well as emerging trends in the electronic design automation workflow; simulation, synthesis, and layout from HDLs like Verilog and VHDL.
Simulated, synthesized, and routed the RTL design for a Z80-like processor using ModelSim and Cadence Virtuoso as a demonstration of the workflow, going from RTL to Netlist to GDSII.

title: PCM2704 USB Audio DAC PCB
items: Designed a PCB to mount on a cell phone to restore the 3.5 mm audio jack with an integrated solution.
From a suggested schematic in the IC's datasheet, created a bill of materials, revised it based on component cost and availability, and created a PCB layout in KiCAD.
Identified a flaw in the PCB design which prevented the board and host from establishing correct data roles.

title: Frequency \& Time Domain Simulation with Model Order Reduction
items: Programmed a frequency domain circuit simulator in MATLAB using modified nodal analysis, then added time domain simulation using either backward Euler or trapezoidal rule, then added model order reduction.
Validated the simulator by collating the output with circuit analysis performed in ngspice.

title: Design of a Tracking ADC
items: Designed and evaluated a 4-bit tracking ADC; a simple Nyquist Rate ADC consisting of a comparator, counter, and feedback DAC in Cadence Virtuoso.
Assembled the comparator and DAC in the schematic editor, and the counter in both Verilog and Verilog-AMS.

title: Micro-Architectural Optimization Tutorial Paper
items: Authored a tutorial paper on application-specific micro-architectural optimization to form an understanding of how hardware and software design may inform each other and to demonstrate technical writing.
Examined graph theory, specifically how dataflow graphs may be observed and manipulated with various optimization methods to improve the efficiency of a potential micro-architecture.

title: CUTS Converter - A Digital Signal Processing Experiment
items: Wrote a C program to convert files for storage on an audio cassette as an exercise in DSP techniques (\textcolor{cyan}{\href{https://github.com/L28E/CUTS-Converter}{link}}).
Utilized frequency shift keying (FSK) for modulation and asynchronous FSK detection for demodulation, including 2 band pass filters, 2 envelope detectors, and decision logic.
Debugged and verified the program using GDB and gnuplot.

title: ``A Crash Course in Electrical Engineering'' - Presentation for Local Cub Scouts
items: Created a presentation for youths age 8 to 10 to pique their interest in electronics, starting at first principles and weaving a trail of math, physics, chemistry which leads to modern computing.
Used props and breadboard circuits, and answered questions to aid explanation to a non-technical audience.

title: Estimating Blood Pressure with Machine Learning
items: Led 3 peers in developing different neural network models in Python to estimate blood pressure from biometric signals previously recorded with a watch-like device.
Determined the critical path, set milestones, assessed progress, and provided technical support to the team.

Achieved a mean absolute error of 1.98 mmHg for systolic and 1.23 mmHg for diastolic pressure with ECG signals and random forest regression, meeting the AAMI standard for automated blood pressure monitors.

title: Various VHDL Designs
items: Created RTL designs for a pipelined array multiplier, 8x8 synchronous FIFO buffer (using memory from the IP catalog), and a PRBS generator on an Altera Cyclone V FPGA using VHDL and Quartus Prime for synthesis.

title: Verilog Signed Serial Multiplier
items: Created a RTL Design for a 8 x 9 bit signed serial multiplier in Verilog.
Simulated, synthesized, and routed the design with a 65 nm TSMC process in Cadence Virtuoso.
Conducted design rule checks and evaluated the functionality, performance, and power dissipation of the design at different levels of abstraction.

title: x86 Assembly Game
items: Programmed the game ``Chonker's Escape'' in x86 assembly as an exercise in low-level programming.
Implemented pseudo-random number generation to place rocks at the bottom of the screen, and the ``chonker'', controlled by software interrupts for keyboard input, must avoid the rocks as it burrows.
Demonstrated embedded topics through coursework; interrupt handling on a STM32, I2C and SPI on Arduino.

title: CSES Senior Design Competition Director
items: Created a challenging and engaging problem statement for senior students participating in the Carleton Engineering Competition — build a robotic shot put device from the available materials.

Selected materials which facilitated a variety of solutions while excluding elastic elements for difficulty, wrote the judging criteria, and collaborated with other directors to host a successful competition.

title: Remote Live View
items: Programmed a small full-stack Java web app for a Raspberry Pi to expose the live view and settings of a DSLR camera through a Wi-Fi hotspot.
Used the libgphoto2 library for camera access, JNA for Java bindings to the library, Jetty as an embedded server to serve the web interface, and hostapd + dnsmasq to provide an access point.

title: ``Pseudo-Holographic Pyramid''
items: Collaborated with 5 peers to build a “Pseudo-Holographic Pyramid”; a Raspberry Pi-based multi-media device which responded to voice commands, turning to show the desired face to the user.

Developed the graphical and voice interface, and rotation in Python. Used data analysis libraries to calculate the angle of the audio source in a stereo recording, and therefore the relative angle the user.

title: Technical Concept Project - Communication Skills for Engineering Student (CCDP 2100)
items: Collaborated with peers to research the engineering concepts underlying upper limb prosthetics, and present findings in spoken and written form to a non-technical audience.
Co-presented the arm as; a kinematic system, a bio-electric system, and a programmatic system.
Authored a final technical report presenting the merit of object-oriented programming in prosthetic devices.

title: Honourable Mention - U of T ``Ask a Laureate'' High School Essay Contest
items: Received an Honourable mention for my essay: ``Spent Nuclear Fuel: The Forlorn - or Fantastic Fate of `Formerly' Fissile Material'', and was subsequently invited to a lecture and lunch.
Prioritized clear, concise, grammatically correct writing to condense important points into a 600 word limit, with some chemical insight and accurate chemical explanations.
